metadata.case_name: Collector of Malabar v. V.P. Abdul Azeez

facts.text: Respondent assessed to income-tax for various years with total outstanding tax of about Rs. 70,000.

Some amount recovered by Collector under certificate from Income Tax Officer u/s 46(2) Income Tax Act and by ITO u/s 46(5A), leaving arrears of about Rs. 61,668 for assessment years 1943-44, 1945-46 to 1948-49.

Income Tax Officer discovered respondent sold properties between November 18, 1947 and March 25, 1948 for about Rs. 23,100 after demand notice on November 6, 1947; paid only Rs. 10,500 towards arrears.

Respondent closed business at Cannanore in August 1947 but set up firm V.P. Abdul Azeez Bros. at Tellichery in 1948 with one major and four minor sons; claimed capital from wife's jewels, but ITO held firm belonged to respondent.
Income Tax Officer communicated facts to Collector, who made independent enquiries and believed respondent wilfully withholding payment and guilty of fraudulent conduct evading tax.
Certificate issued by Income Tax Officer to Collector u/s 46(2) Income Tax Act.
Collector issued warrant of arrest u/s 48 Madras Revenue Recovery Act on March 10, 1954.
Respondent arrested on June 1, 1954 and lodged in Central Jail, Cannanore.
Respondent filed petition u/s 491 CrPC in Madras High Court for habeas corpus and release.

Madras High Court (Mack J. and Krishnaswami Nayudu J.) allowed petition on July 23, 1954, holding arrest illegal; Mack J.: s.48 ultra vires Art.22, s.46(2) ultra Art.14; Nayudu J.: s.46(2)+s.48 ultra Art.14, s.48 ultra Art.21 (no hearing, no 24-hr production).
Madras High Court granted certificate u/Art.132(1) Constitution that case involved substantial question of law as to interpretation of Constitution.
Respondent about 70 years old, suffering from serious ill health including paralysis at time of arrest.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.48 of Madras Revenue Recovery Act and/or s.46(2) of Indian Income Tax Act violate Arts. 14, 19, 21, 22 of Constitution.
Whether s.46(2) Income Tax Act authorizes Collector to arrest defaulter, or only recovery without arrest.
Whether s.48 requires opportunity to be heard before issuing warrant of arrest, as Collector must have reason to believe wilful withholding or fraudulent conduct.
Whether s.48 provides for release of defaulter on payment of arrears.

petitioner_arguments.text: Neither s.48 of Madras Act nor s.46(2) Income Tax Act violates Arts. 14,19,21,22; s.46(2) valid, authorizes Collector to recover arrears as land revenue.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Arts. 14,19,21,22 Constitution; s.46(2) Income Tax Act

respondent_arguments.text: s.48 Madras Act and s.46(2) Income Tax Act offend Arts.14,19,21,22.

s.46(2) Income Tax Act authorizes only recovery of arrears, no authority to arrest defaulter; arrest only under s.48, which requires prior opportunity to be heard before warrant as belief cannot form without hearing.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.46(2) Income Tax Act; s.48 Madras Act

respondent_arguments.text: s.48 has no provision for release on payment of arrears.

court_reasoning.text: Art.19(1)(a)-(e),(g) controlled by Art.21; if deprivation of liberty under valid law per Art.21, no infraction of Art.19; procedure established by law means valid State law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principal question: whether deprivation per valid law.

court_reasoning.text: Arrest not 'arrest or detention' under Art.22; for civil debt recovery as arrears of land revenue, not criminal/quasi-criminal.
Follows Purshottam Halai: arrest u/s.13 Bombay Land Revenue Act (similar) per s.46(2) certificate is procedure established by law, not violating Art.21 or 14.

s.46(2) authorizes recovery as land revenue arrears, including arrest u/s.48 as mode per s.5 Madras Act (sale of property or execution against person); not punishment but coercive recovery when wilful/fraudulent.
No prior hearing required u/s.48; Collector needs rational belief based on material, court can review; material from affidavits (sales, firm) sufficient.
Release possible via proviso s.46(2) Income Tax Act (powers as Civil Court); like CPC s.58, release on payment; arrears payment removes condition.

holdings.text: Neither s.48 Madras Revenue Recovery Act nor s.46(2) Indian Income Tax Act violates Arts.14,19,21,22 Constitution.
Arrest under s.48 after s.46(2) certificate is lawful procedure for recovery of tax arrears as land revenue, not punishment.
No prior hearing required before arrest u/s.48 if Collector has rational belief based on material.
Defaulter entitled to release on payment of arrears via Collector's powers under proviso to s.46(2) Income Tax Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: A.K. Gopalan v. The State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.19 rights subordinate to Art.21; procedure by valid law suffices.

precedents_cited.case_name: The State of Punjab v. Ajaib Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Custody for recovery not 'arrest/detention' under Art.22.

precedents_cited.case_name: Purshottam Govindji Halai v. Shree B.B. Desai, Additional Collector of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: s.46(2) Income Tax Act valid, not ultra Art.14/21; arrest under revenue recovery law lawful.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Tested for violation; arrest per valid law under Art.21 does not infringe others.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Revenue Recovery Act (Act 11 of 1864)
statutes_cited.relevance: Modes of recovery include arrest if wilful/fraudulent withholding after property sale fails; valid procedure.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Authorizes recovery of arrears as land revenue; Collector has civil court powers for release.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for habeas petition in High Court.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Analogy for release on payment via s.46(2) proviso.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed with costs; High Court judgment set aside; respondent's arrest held legal and justified under ss.46(2) Income Tax Act and 48 Madras Revenue Recovery Act; no constitutional violation.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed, respondent not entitled to release on habeas grounds.

key_quotes.text: "Under Art. 21 Procedure established by law means procedure enacted by a law made by the State... If the law is valid then he has been lawfully deprived of his personal liberty."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The arrest of the defaulter is one of the modes, by which the arrears of revenue can be recovered... arrest is no more than a mode for recovery of the amount due."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies arrest as recovery mechanism, not punishment.

key_quotes.text: "The Collector, therefore, must have some material upon which he bases his belief-a belief which must be rational belief."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Standard for Collector's belief under s.48.
